title: 109_hr1059
content:
The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" aims to establish a policy of nondiscrimination based on sexual orientation in the Armed Forces by repealing previous laws that allowed for discrimination. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" establishes a policy of nondiscrimination based on sexual orientation in the Armed Forces, prohibiting discrimination against any member or potential member based on sexual orientation. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation, including denial of accession or personnel actions. The Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security cannot establish policies based on sexual orientation. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation. The Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security can enforce regulations on conduct without regard to sexual orientation. Re-accession into the armed forces is permitted for individuals separated for homosexuality, bisexuality, or homosexual conduct. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation, including heterosexuality, homosexuality, or bisexuality. Re-accession into the armed forces is permitted for individuals separated for such conduct. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2005" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation, including re-accession for individuals separated for such conduct. Title 10, United States Code, is amended to include protections against sexual orientation discrimination. SEC. 5. BENEFITS.

This Act does not require the provision of dependent benefits that violate the Defense of Marriage Act.

SEC. 6. NO PRIVATE CAUSE OF ACTION FOR DAMAGES.

There is no private cause of action for damages under this Act.

SEC. 7. REGULATIONS. The Secretary of Defense must revise Department of Defense regulations within 90 days to implement section 656 of title 10, United States Code. Military departments must also revise their regulations within 180 days to include sexual orientation nondiscrimination in equal opportunity policies and training programs. The Secretary of Defense and military departments must revise regulations to eliminate involuntary discharges based on sexual orientation and include sexual orientation discrimination in victims' advocacy programs. Regulations governing personal conduct of Armed Forces members should be written and enforced without regard to sexual orientation. Forces must adhere to regulations without considering sexual orientation, as defined in section 656(f) of title 10, United States Code.
